The Secretary will revise regulations on tobacco products to include additional restrictions on marketing and advertising within 18 months of the enactment of the subchapter. Warnings on cigarettes and smokeless tobacco will also be required within the same timeframe. The Secretary will promulgate regulations for warnings on cigarette and smokeless tobacco labeling and advertisements, conforming to specified specifications. It will be unlawful to advertise tobacco products on electronic communication mediums under FCC jurisdiction. Regulations on ingredients in tobacco products will be promulgated within 18 months of enactment. The regulations for tobacco products must adhere to the specifications outlined in Title IF of the Proposed Resolution. Failure to approve or disapprove an ingredient's safety within the review period does not constitute approval. Manufacturers cannot claim reduced risk in labeling or ads without Secretary approval. This section does not limit the Secretary's authority under other provisions of the Act. "SEC. 567. STATE TOBACCO CONTROL PROGRAMS." Effective 2 years after enactment, States must have a tobacco control program conforming to the model program established by the Secretary to receive funds under this Act. The model program includes requiring tobacco sellers to obtain a license and comply with relevant Act requirements. The Act requires tobacco product retailers to comply with various regulations, including prohibiting the resale of tobacco products to individuals under 18, conducting compliance inspections, setting performance objectives for reducing violations, imposing penalties for non-compliance, and including other necessary provisions. The Secretary may include provisions to protect public health. If a State fails to implement a tobacco control program or meet performance objectives, up to 20% of funds can be withheld. Within a year, Federal licensing requirements will be established for tobacco retailers on Federal property or in States without effective tobacco laws. The Federal tobacco control requirements must align with the Model State Program. The Secretary has the authority to order a retailer to stop selling tobacco products if they violate the Act. Indian tribes operating tobacco retailers on reservations are treated as States. SEC. 7. GENERAL PROVISIONS. Amends Section 301 to include violations related to tobacco products. Amends Section 701 to allow the Secretary to acquire information on tobacco products and disclose it for public health protection. 

SEC. 8. REPEAL. SEC. 8. REPEAL. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act and the Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986 will be repealed when new regulations under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act take effect.
